text.b: Appendix D – Meetings and Field Visits

page.text: Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
For Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development
The project is located in Tangipahoa Parish, Louisiana along U.S. Highway 51 Business
beginning approximately 1.5 miles south of Interstate 12 at Ponchatoula Creek and runs
northward approximately 1.7 miles to just north of Interstate 12 near the Hammond Mall Drive.
Within the project area, for about a quarter mile south of Interstate 12, near Seale Place Drive
and Club Deluxe Road, is the heavily congested stretch of U.S. 51 Business where the free flow
and safe movement of traffic is significantly altered by the intricate maneuvering of the heavy
volume of trucks. The opportunity to provide for the complex maneuvering of these large
vehicles harmoniously with the motoring public is the essence of this project.
Potential funding sources for this project that may be available in FY 11/12 include sources as:
Safety Funds, federal funding through the Department’s Safety Program;
Surplus E Funds, transportation funding from the 2007 State Legislative session;
Local Funds; the City of Hammond is a beneficiary of roadway improvements.
State Project No. 454-03-0065 (WB off ramp improvements) $350,000
State Project No. 452-90-0155 (Interstate 55 ramps at US 190) $1,250,000
Potential funding for the project totals:
The Stage 0 Study of the project corridor recognizes a strong need to improve the congested
conditions that exist between Interstate 12 and Club Deluxe Road. The feasibility of
improvements is clearly demonstrated and advancement of the project to Stage 1, Environmental,
The remaining section of the project along the medical corridor, southward to Ponchatoula
Creek, will continue to function reasonably well under the existing two-way-left-turn-lane
(TWLTL) condition and no improvements are recognized as necessary.
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
For Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development
Alternate A includes refurbishing existing pavement and striping for median treatment with
minimal pavement widening and shoulder considerations. Improvement features considered
1. Widening existing pavement to accommodate a future six lane section under Interstate 12,
being two through lanes and one left turn only in each direction. Twelve foot wide travel
lanes are desirable with the heavy truck volume.
2. The Interstate 12 eastbound exit ramp is configured to accommodate an additional lane
designated as an exit lane to Seale Place Drive. This lane along the exit ramp can also
provide for through movements to the eastbound entrance ramp or northbound left turns.
3. The Interstate 12 eastbound exit ramp is also configured to accommodate a southbound
right turn lane that operates in conjunction with a designated entry lane to Petro Truck
4. A variable width median is added to accommodate designated mid-block left turn
5. One southbound through lane is preferred between Seale Place Drive and Club Deluxe
Road so that trucks exiting northbound from Petro Truck Stop will only have to cross over
one lane of traffic, thereby reducing potential traffic conflicts.
6. Northbound trucks exiting Petro Truck Stop have a protected entry lane as a second
northbound lane begins within the median entry.
7. On the southbound approach to Club Deluxe Road, a lane for right turns only is added and
the left turn only to TK Valve Company is maintained and improved. One southbound
through lane will continue across Club Deluxe Road.
8. On the eastbound approach of Club Deluxe Road, pavement widening is proposed to
accommodate two lanes. One lane is designated for right turns only and the other as a
combined left turn lane and through lane for TK Valve Company.

text.b: Preliminary Environmental Evaluation of Alternate A

page.text: A preliminary environmental review of Alternate A does not appear to have a significant effect
on the environment. The widening and striping project is expected to be constructed without the
need for additional right-of-way or displacements. The requirements of the National
Environmental Policy Act could possibly be met with a Categorical Exclusion.

text.b: Preliminary Cost Estimate for Alternate A

page.text: Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
For Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development
Alternate B includes refurbishing existing pavement and striping with minimal pavement
widening and shoulder considerations. Alternate B has made accommodations for moderate U-
turns for the access of driveways in the project corridor. Access to driveways from Interstate 12
or to return to Interstate 12 will require U-turn movements at a Club Deluxe Road roundabout.
Improvement features considered under Alternate B include:
1. The Interstate 12 eastbound exit ramp is configured to accommodate an additional lane
designated as an exit lane to Seale Place Drive. This lane along the exit ramp can also
provide for through movements to the eastbound entrance ramp or northbound left turns.
2. Existing conditions remain under Interstate 12 and no improvements are proposed.
3. The Interstate 12 eastbound exit ramp is also configured to accommodate a southbound
right turn lane that operates in conjunction with a designated entry lane to Petro Truck
4. A variable width median is added to accommodate designated left turn movements and
crossovers. Left turn bays are accommodating to Seale Place Drive and the Mobil Gas
Station. A crossover is allows only left turns from Seale Place Drive.
5. One southbound through lane is preferred between Seale Place Drive and Club Deluxe
Road so that trucks exiting northbound from Petro Truck Stop will enter directly into a
lane of traffic, thereby reducing potential traffic conflicts.
6. A single lane roundabout is introduced at US 51B and Club Deluxe Road to allow U-turn
7. Northbound trucks exit Petro Truck Stop southbound and make a U-turn at Club Deluxe

text.b: Preliminary Environmental Evaluation of Alternate B

page.text: A preliminary environmental review of Alternate B does not appear to have a significant effect
on the environment. However, there appears to be a need for additional right-of-way at the Club
Deluxe Road intersection as well as the relocation of parts of three businesses in the area. The
requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act could possibly be met with an

text.b: Preliminary Cost Estimate for Alternate B

page.text: Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
For Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development
Alternate C includes refurbishing existing pavement and striping with pavement widening.
Alternate C also has accommodations for significant U-turn movements in lieu of traditional
median treatment for left-turn movements. Roundabouts located at the major intersections along
the corridor provide for free flow movements and U-turn capabilities for the access to driveways
in the project area. Approaching from Interstate 12 or returning to Interstate 12 will require U-
turn movements at the Club Deluxe Road roundabout. The at-grade intersections of US 51B and
both the eastbound and westbound ramps for Interstate 12 benefit from free flow of roundabouts.
Project conditions and the spacing of signalized intersections along the corridor lend to multiple
roundabouts. Improvement features considered under Alternate C include:
1. Roundabouts at each intersecting ramp of Interstate 12 and US 51B.
2. Four mainline travel lanes (two in each direction) northward from Club Deluxe Road.
3. A northbound approach lane is added to US 51B at Club Deluxe Road.
4. A second lane is added to the eastbound exit ramp of Interstate 12 upon the approach to
5. Median crossovers are removed and access is provided to all driveways by U-turn
6. All driveway exits are right turns.

text.b: Preliminary Environmental Evaluation of Alternate C

page.text: A preliminary environmental evaluation of Alternate C does not appear to have a significant
effect on the environment. However, there is a need for additional right-of-way at the Club
Deluxe Road intersection as well as the relocation of parts of three businesses in the area. Also,
locating roundabouts at interstate ramps are not common to the area and may require additional
evaluation of impacts to the system. The requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act
could possibly be met with an Environmental Impact Statement.

text.b: Preliminary Cost Estimate for Alternate C
Summary of Conditions for Current State Projects

page.text: Study alternates were developed as a combination of individual improvements, some of which
are included in current State Projects and may include:
1. US 51B widening at I-12 may be implemented separately or with either Alternate A or B.
2. Interstate 12 westbound off ramp improvements. Significant heavy truck traffic may lend
dual left turn lanes less efficient and safe, therefore dual left turn lanes are not included in
the study alternates. See Appendix C.
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
The purpose of this project is to reduce existing traffic congestion and minimize
travel delays, address projected traffic increases and to alleviate conflicting
business access within the project corridor. The project is to provide for the safe
weaving/turning of trucks and eliminate the “gridlock” conditions that impair
emergency vehicles and the efficient flow of traffic in the project area.
There is a need to address the operational impacts of “mid-block” left turn
movements and the access demands for driveways at adjacent properties that are
densely located along the corridor. These left turn movements and the high
volume of trucks contribute significantly to congestion in the “midblock” segment
south of Interstate 12. The block between Club Deluxe Road and the east bound I-
12 ramp terminal is bounded by signalized intersections. The condition where
long queues are formed due to stopped delays associated with upstream signals is a
contributing factor in the congestion and delays that occur at un-signalized access
points. Emergency vehicles that service the nearby N. Oaks Medical Center
experience delays in the congested corridor and often times avoid the potential
delays by choosing a longer and more circuitous route.
Roadway considerations in the project area, intending a reduction in traffic congestion
and travel time, are to recognize a complex intermix of vehicle types, the need for
business access along the corridor and through lane efficiency. Feasible solutions are
identifiable for this complicated traffic condition.
The technical concerns of a transitional arterial and the correlation of condensed access
features are prevalent in the development of roadway improvements. The congested
qualities lend to speed reduction, lane designation, and recognition of the adverse
Improved speeds and travel times are recognized as beneficial to the environment though
historically encouragement of growth may impact cultural and historical resources.
Roadway improvements can be in community with sensitive environments. However,
there are no historical sites identified in the project area. The National Environmental
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
Policy Act of 1970 requires transportation agencies to examine potential social and
environmental impacts when considering proposed projects.
Immediate to the project corridor are the three distinct jurisdictional entities that
commonly provide public trusts in the realm of transportation improvements. The
interchange at Interstate 12 and U.S. Highway 51 Business is characteristic of federal
The state is generally associated with appropriating funding for its highway system. The
state recently received $695 million in additional funding to be used for road
construction, preconstruction, ports and flood protection projects across the state. The
additional funds were appropriated during the 2007 Louisiana Legislative session.
The City of Hammond has provisions for funding improvements to the local roadway
Funding programs for this project that may be available in FY 11/12 include sources as:
1. Safety Funds, federal funding through the Department’s Safety Program;
2. Surplus E Funds, transportation funding from the 2007 State Legislative session;
3. Local Funds, the City of Hammond is a beneficiary of roadway improvements.

text.b: Identify and Describe a Project that will address the Purpose and

page.text: The US 51B corridor services a thriving and expanding community as an urban arterial
with a conventional diamond interchange that provides the community with immediate
access to I-12. Other interchanges in the community that provide interstate access
include the LA 22/I-55 interchange near Ponchatoula, the US 190/I-55 interchange, the
US 51/I-55 interchange, and the LA. 3234/I-55 interchange, all of which access the I-12
corridor circuitously from I-55 via the I-55/I-12 cloverleaf interchange. There is access
to I-12 by a diamond interchange at LA 3158 located approximately two and a half miles
The interchange at I-12 services trucks from both the I-55 and I-12 corridors with
intricate routing to two large truck service facilities in the southwestern and southeastern
quadrants of the interchange and a second smaller truck generator in the southeastern
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
quadrant. In the northwest quadrant, the interchange services a major shopping mall
complex contributing to truck traffic in the interchange area.
North of I-12, US 51B is a four lane principal urban arterial roadway with a raised
median and dedicated left-turn lanes. The US 51B corridor supports numerous
South of I-12, between Ponchatoula Creek and Club Deluxe Road, the US 51B corridor
serves as a minor arterial and is the connector between two municipalities in close
proximity, Hammond to the north and Ponchatoula to the south. Along this segment of
the corridor is the expanding North Oaks Medical Center, a key generator of visitor and
commuter traffic as well as emergency vehicle traffic. In this area of the project, US 51B
is a two-way, one-lane roadway in each direction with a two-way left-turn lane. Land use
in this area is both residential and commercial.
South of Interstate 12 and north of Club Deluxe Road, the US 51B corridor is a four lane
minor urban arterial roadway with a raised median and a two-way left-turn lane. This
segment of the roadway is bounded by a signalized intersection at the ramp terminal of
east bound I-12 and the signalized intersection at Club Deluxe Road. Club Deluxe Road
is a two way undivided roadway with one lane in each direction. There are two south
bound lanes of US 51B that merge into one lane at the approach to the Club Deluxe Road
intersection. At this location, left turn movements must queue in a single south bound
travel lane contributing to traffic congestion in the area. There is one north bound lane
through the Club Deluxe Road intersection that transitions to two lanes approaching
The lane configuration of US 51B through the I-12 interchange is constricted by the
length of the I-12 bridge overpass and presently operates as a five lane section, two
through lanes in each direction with dedicated left turn lanes divided by a barrier between
east and west bound turns. The dedicated left turn lane onto west bound I-12 is a shorter
length than that for the east bound I-12 left turn lane.
Interstate 55 can also be accessed from US 51B via the local roadway network. The two
urban collector roadways in the network parallel I-12 from US 51 B to US 51 to the west.
CF Fagan Drive is located to the north of the Hammond Area shopping mall. Club
Deluxe Road is located south of the truck service facilities along US 51B. There is
interstate access from US 51 with a trumpet interchange at I-55.
Existing traffic counts for the project were recently taken at various locations in the
project area. Turning movement counts were taken at intersections throughout the
project and at certain driveway locations that were known to experience or contribute to
delays in the corridor. A summary of selected findings is listed in the following tables.
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana

text.i: Source: Existing Traffic Volumes prepared by Urban Systems, Inc. dated October 2008.

page.text: Ponchatoula Creek to Club Deluxe Road

text.i: Source: Existing Traffic Volumes prepared by Urban Systems, Inc. dated October 2008.

page.text: Intersection Level of Service and Capacity Analysis Results
EB I-12 Ramps at US 51 B
US 51 B at Seale Place Dr
US 51 B at Club Deluxe Rd
EB Club Deluxe Rd at US 51 B
US 51 B at N. Oaks Drive
US 51 B at Medical Arts Plaza
The LOS results for specific intersections can be somewhat misleading in this case. Most
intersection approaches are listed as LOS A, B, C, and D with few instances of E and F.
In heavily congested areas, occasionally traffic volumes counted are the actual number of
vehicles that are “able” to get through the intersection rather than the number of vehicles
that are “trying” to get through the intersection. Based on visual observation during the
AM and PM commuting hours, traffic was steady but moved fairly well. The heaviest
delays noticed were in the early to mid afternoon hours.
Conditions at the project site have a unique and potentially hazardous presence with the
operation and accessibility of the two major truck stop facilities located south of
Interstate 12. The facilities service a national array of trucking and delivery vehicles.
The Petro Stopping Center is open 24 hours serving both professional drivers and
interstate motorists. Petro Truck Stop is located in the southwestern quadrant of the
There are multiple fueling lanes that are separate from the main building eliminating
fueling conflicts with smaller vehicles, increasing safety, and ease of access. Petro
Centers offer Petro-Lube a preventative maintenance for trucks. CAT Scales are
available to provide a certified weigh. A large number of paved parking spaces are
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
available with wider spaces, and separate truck and auto parking. Intermixed services
include The Iron Skillet Restaurant and leisure time activities for drivers.
The Pilot Truck Stop is located in the southeastern quadrant of the interchange at
Interstate 12. The truck stop and convenience store is open 24 hours serving both
The fueling stations for Pilot Truck Stop are poorly operated contributing significantly to
roadway congestion and delays in the project area. The clockwise movement of trucks
through the fueling station provides an insufficient queue along Seale Place Drive for
trucks awaiting access to the station. The queue conflicts with trucks exiting the site and
many times extends out to US 51B. A counterclockwise circulation with trucks being
able to queue on the station site may improve conditions along US 51B.
The operational characteristics and the high volume of trucks in the project area, as well
as, the actual vehicle operation potentially create an undesirable surrounding and
hazardous condition. It is important to strive to improve the knowledge of all highway
users to minimize the likelihood of a crash with a large truck, and to educate people about
how to share the road safely with large trucks and buses.

text.b: 3.2 Goals for successfully accomplishing the project

page.text: The goals and objectives of the project include the following:
1. To develop a corridor plan that will improve operations and contribute to a
reduction of traffic congestion in the area.
2. To provide safe and efficient access through the corridor for emergency vehicles
3. To provide for safe and efficient truck circulation within the corridor and reduce
the potential for “gridlock” conditions created by the conflict of passenger vehicles
4. To provide optimum timing for existing signalization to allow for operations at a
5. To minimize the need for additional right-of-way acquisition and business
6. To provide effective access to and from driveways that serve businesses along the
7. To avoid or minimize impacts to the human and/or natural environment.
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
A significant consideration for improvements in this project area is median treatment
which is an important means of reducing accidents and delay on urban arterial highways.
Common median treatments include the two-way left-turn lane, the continuous left-turn
lane, the alternating left-turn lane, the raised median divider with left-turn deceleration
lanes, and the median barrier with no direct left-turn access. The selection of median
treatment for an arterial highway is based on geometric and operational conditions.
The proposed improvements described as Alternate A includes refurbishing existing
pavement and striping for median treatment with minimal pavement widening and
shoulder considerations. Improvement features considered under Alternate A include:
1. Widening existing pavement to accommodate a future six lane section under
Interstate 12, being two through lanes and one left turn only in each direction.
Twelve foot wide travel lanes are desirable with the heavy truck volume.
2. The Interstate 12 eastbound exit ramp is configured to accommodate an additional
lane designated as an exit lane to Seale Place Drive. This lane along the exit ramp
can also provide for through movements to the eastbound entrance ramp or
3. The Interstate 12 eastbound exit ramp is also configured to accommodate a
southbound right turn lane that operates in conjunction with a designated entry
4. A variable width median is added to accommodate designated mid-block left turn
5. One southbound through lane is preferred between Seale Place Drive and Club
Deluxe Road so that trucks exiting northbound from Petro Truck Stop will only
have to cross over one lane of traffic, thereby reducing potential traffic conflicts.
6. Northbound trucks exiting Petro Truck Stop have a protected entry lane as a
second northbound lane begins within the median entry.
7. On the southbound approach to Club Deluxe Road, a lane for right turns only is
added and the left turn only to TK Valve Company is maintained and improved.
One southbound through lane will continue across Club Deluxe Road.
8. On the eastbound approach of Club Deluxe Road, pavement widening is proposed
to accommodate two lanes. One lane is designated for right turns only and the
other as a left turn lane and through lane for TK Valve Company.
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
3.3.1 Basic Design Criteria for Alternate A

text.i: UA-1 Principal Urban Arterial (Club Deluxe Road to I-12)
UA- 2 Minor Urban Arterial (Ponchatoula Creek to Club Deluxe
Existing R/W, 8 ft. back of curb (minimum)

page.text: 3.3.2 Major Design Features of Alternate A
Some of the major features incorporated into the proposed alternatives that are considered
to improve traffic conditions may include:
1. Trucks using the designated left turn lane from southbound US 51B to Seale Place
Drive are removed from the through lane of US 51B reducing southbound delays.
2. The free flow right turn into Petro Truck Stop from the eastbound exit ramp of
3. Northbound trucks exiting Petro Truck Stop must cross only one southbound lane
and are provided a median protected merge lane entering northbound traffic. This
will provide for a free flow condition upon gaps in the southbound traffic flow.
4. Trucks intending the eastbound entry ramp of Interstate 12 can free flow from
Seale Place Drive and out of the Pilot Truck Stop.
5. Approach lanes are added on US 51B southbound at Club Deluxe Road and on
eastbound Club Deluxe Road at US 51B.
6. The median is configured to discourage trucks crossing US 51B between the Pilot
and Petro Truck Stops at Seale Place Road and disrupting traffic flow.
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
In such a congested area that services such a large volume of various truck movements, it
is essential when considering feasibility of improvements to recognize that present
conditions restrict the applicability of certain criteria and the full and complete
implementation of all principles. Conditions may support a rationale that improvements
though less than minimal may be advantageous. Some of the following conditions may
1. The roadway width under Interstate 12 is restricted by existing bridge columns and
would provide for a 2-ft. horizontal clearance under the structure. Travel lanes
twelve feet wide better accommodate the high truck volumes.
2. One of the two through southbound lanes under I-12 is dropped requiring signing
for a required merge about 200-ft south of ramp intersection. This is achieved to
allow only one southbound lane to continue between Seale Place Drive and Club
Deluxe Road. One southbound lane under Interstate 12 will opt as a left only at
Seale Place with the option to merge right to the through lane.
3. A posted speed of less than forty mile per hour may best facilitate the US 51B
transition area between the major arterial at Interstate 12 and the minor arterial
4. Weaving lengths remain the same for northbound trucks even though conditions
are improved by free flow from both truck stop exits. The need for a higher level
of driver skills and attentiveness may be offset with advanced signing.
3.3.4 Detailed Investigation of Right-of-way and Displacement
At the outset of the development of Alternate A, the desirable condition was to provide
improvements within the existing right-of-way without adverse impacts to adjacent or
fronting properties. This can essentially be accomplished using curbed roadway or
shoulders with a minimum right-of-way of eight feet beyond the back of curb.
It is intended that improvements for Alternate A can be implemented within the existing
right-of-way and that no additional right-of-way is to be acquired.
3.3.5 Detailed Investigation of Utility Relocation Impacts
The information presented in this section will identify the existing utilities affected by the
US Highway 51B project. The information contained herein was gathered through
topographic survey, field visits, and telephone conversations and meetings with the utility
owners. The facilities affected by the project are categorized as follows: 1.) Electric
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
power transmission and distribution lines; 2.) Fiber optic communication lines; 3.) Water
lines; 4.) Sewer and sanitary sewer pipelines.
There are three overhead power lines in the project area that will be impacted. The first
line consists of a vertical and horizontal spacing of 333-ft. situated within the US 51B
and Interstate 12 interchange. The second line consists of a vertical and horizontal
spacing of 326-ft. situated within US 51B and Interstate 12 interchange near the Waffle
House. The third line consists of a vertical and horizontal spacing of 278-ft. situated
within the Club Deluxe Road and US 51B intersection. The power lines are owned by
The Fiber optic communication lines that might be impacted consist of a vertical spacing
of 127-ft. and horizontal spacing of 177-ft. in the location within the interchange of US
51B and Interstate 12 near the Waffle House. The fiber optic communication lines are
owned by AT&T. The cables are buried approximately twelve feet below the surface and
The Water lines that are impacted consist of a vertical spacing of 133-ft. in the location
within the interchange of US 51B and Interstate 12 by the Waffle House and also a
vertical spacing of 174-ft. located in the Seale Place Dr. and US 51B intersection. The
water lines are owned by the City of Hammond.
There are four underground sewer lines in the project area that will be impacted. The
first line consists of a vertical spacing of 168-ft. located in the intersection of US 51B and
Interstate 12. The second and third line impacted consist of a vertical spacing of 137-ft.
and a horizontal spacing of 139-ft. located in the interchange of US 51B and Interstate 12
near the Waffle House. The fourth line impacted consists of a vertical spacing 85-ft.
located within the intersection of Club Deluxe Road and US 51B. The sewer lines are
owned by the City of Hammond.
A reasonable alternative being Alternate B includes refurbishing existing pavement and
striping with minimal pavement widening and shoulder considerations. Alternate B has
made accommodations for moderate U-turns for the access of driveways in the project
corridor. Access to driveways from Interstate 12 or to return to Interstate 12 will require
U-turn movements at Club Deluxe Road roundabout. Improvement features considered
1. The Interstate 12 eastbound exit ramp is configured to accommodate an additional
lane designated as an exit lane to Seale Place Drive. This lane along the exit ramp can
also provide for through movements to the eastbound entrance ramp or northbound
2. Existing conditions remain under Interstate 12 and no improvements are proposed.

for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
3. The Interstate 12 eastbound exit ramp is also configured to accommodate a
southbound right turn lane that operates in conjunction with a designated entry lane to
4. A variable width median is added to accommodate designated left turn movements.
Left turn bays are accommodating to Seale Place Drive and the Mobil Gas Station.
Crossovers from Seale Place Drive are not allowed.
5. One southbound through lane is preferred between Seale Place Drive and Club Deluxe
Road so that trucks exiting northbound from Petro Truck Stop will enter directly into a
lane of traffic, thereby reducing potential traffic conflicts.
6. A single lane roundabout is introduced at US 51B and Club Deluxe Road to allow U-
turn movements to and from Interstate 12.
7. Northbound trucks exit Petro Truck Stop southbound and make a U-turn at Club

UA- 2 Minor Urban Arterial (Ponchatoula Creek to Club Deluxe

page.text: 3.4.2 Major Design Features of Alternate B
Some of the major features incorporated into Alternative B are considered to improve
1. Trucks using the designated left turn lane from southbound US 51B to Seale Place
Drive are removed from the through lane of US 51B reducing southbound delays.
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
2. The free flow right turn into Petro Truck Stop from the eastbound exit ramp of
3. Northbound trucks exiting Petro Truck Stop have a free flow entry to the
southbound lane upon gaps in the single lane traffic flow.
4. Trucks intending the eastbound entry ramp of Interstate 12 can free flow from
Seale Place Drive and out of the Pilot Truck Stop.
5. Approach lanes from all directions at Club Deluxe Road yield upon entry to the
single lane roundabout allowing all movements a free flow condition.
6. The median is configured to discourage trucks crossing US 51B between the Pilot
and Petro Truck Stops at Seale Place Road.
7. Raised medians are desirable to manage mid-block left turns at established
openings, though may lend to some unwanted travel movements and patterns.
Southbound traffic has access to all existing driveways by use of the U-turn feature of the
single lane roundabout located at the Club Deluxe Road intersection. Northbound traffic
has limited access to driveways along the west side of US 51B by using Club Deluxe
Road or the one designated left turn bay. All driveways must exit as a right turn only, a
feature that may maintain free flow speed. Management techniques for access can
increase roadway capacity, better manage congestion and reduce crash conditions.
A major and unique concept included with Alternate B is the single lane roundabout.
Roundabouts provide free flow movements using the concept to yield upon entry.
Roundabouts can reduce the number of accidents and those with serious injury, by
reducing the speeds in which vehicles are traveling to about 20 mph instead of 45 mph.
Single lane roundabouts provide the opportunity to accommodate a moderate number of
3.4.2.3 Operations of a Single Lane Roundabout with
The single lane roundabout is designed with a truck apron to accommodate the turning
radius of large trucks and trailers. The rear wheels of the trailer ride up onto the truck
apron. Though a truck apron may be provided, drivers should be aware that trucks may
utilize the full lane width and should follow behind and not adjacent to or pass trucks
through a roundabout. Trucks should follow the same ‘slow down on approach’ and
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
‘yield upon entry’ rules for entering and exiting as other motorist. It may be desirable
that the local truck stops offer truckers a classroom tutorial on operating in a roundabout.
When driving in a roundabout, do not impede emergency vehicles. Move through and
exit the roundabout to ensure emergency personnel get to their intended destination
There are conditions in Alternate B that are practicable and warrant exceptions to desired
criteria. Some of those conditions may include:
1. One of the two through southbound lanes under I-12 is dropped requiring a
decision to merge about 200-ft south of ramp intersection. This is achieved to
allow only one southbound lane to continue between Seale Place Drive and Club
Deluxe Road. One southbound lane under Interstate 12 will opt as a left only at
Seale Place with the option to merge right to the through lane.
2. A posted speed of less than forty miles per hour may best facilitate the US 51B
transition area between the major arterial at Interstate 12 and the minor arterial
south of Club Deluxe Road. Operating speeds of 20 miles per hour within and
3. The weaving length remains the same for northbound trucks even though
conditions are improved by free flow from both truck stop exits. The need for a
higher level of driver skills and attentiveness may be offset with advanced signing
3.4.4 Detailed Investigation of Right-of-way and Displacement
The acquisition of right-of-way is minimized by using curbed roadways and shoulders.
This allows for a minimum of eight feet beyond the back of curb for roadway right-of-
way. For Alternate B there are at least three private properties that improvements will
The Deluxe Harvest Fruit and Vegetable Stand located in the northwest quadrant of the
US 51B and Club Deluxe Road intersection and apparently sits upon a tract of land with
approximately 250-ft. of frontage on US 51B and 300-ft. of frontage along Club Deluxe
Road. The fruit stand building can be avoided by the improvements but it would not be
practicable for the operation of the stand to function so close to the improved roadway.
However, there appears to be sufficient remaining acreage to reconstruct the fruit stand
structure on the residual property. Driveway access to the fruit stand is restricted to a
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
The Whiskey Bin Bar is located in the southwest quadrant of the US 51B and Club
Deluxe Road intersection and apparently sits upon a tract of land with approximately
352-ft of frontage along US 51B and 225-ft. or so along Club Deluxe Road. The
structure can be avoided by the improvements by using a curbed roadway and a minimum
right-of-way of 8-ft. from back of curb. Driveway access to the bar is restricted to a
T.K. Valve Company is located along the eastern side of US 51B and apparently sits
upon a tract of land with approximately 543-ft. of frontage along US 51B. There is an
existing driveway located at Club Deluxe Road and is included in the signal cycle of the
A large oak tree is located at the edge of the existing right-of-way and the existing
driveway at T.K. Valve Company. This oak tree will be removed.
It is anticipated that additional right-of-way will be acquired for Alternate B.
3.4.5 Detailed Investigation of Utility Relocation Impacts
The information presented in this section will identify the existing utilities affected by
Alternate B of the project. The information contained herein was gathered through
topographic survey, field visits, and telephone conversations and meetings with the utility
owners. The facilities affected by the project have been categorized as follows: 1.)
Electric power transmission and distribution lines; 2.) Fiber optic communication lines;
3.) Water lines; 4.) Sewer and sanitary sewer pipelines.
1.) There are two overhead power lines in the project area that will be impacted. The
first line consists of a vertical and horizontal spacing of 329-ft. situated within the
US 51B and I-12 intersection near the Waffle House. The second line consists of
a vertical and horizontal spacing of 278-ft. situated within the Club Deluxe Rd.
and US 51B intersection. The owner of the power lines is Entergy
2.) The fiber optic communication lines that may be impacted by the project consist
of a vertical spacing of 129-ft. and horizontal spacing of 169-ft. in the location
within the intersection of US 51B and I-12 near the Waffle House. The owner of
the fiber optic communication lines is AT&T. The cables are buried twelve feet
below the intersection therefore minimum impact should occur.
3.) There are two water lines in the project area that are impacted. The first line
consists of a vertical spacing of 133-ft. in the location within the intersection of
US 51B and I-12 near the Waffle House. The second line consists of a vertical
spacing of 174-ft. located in the Seale Place Dr. and US 51B intersection. The
water lines are owned by the City of Hammond
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
4.) There are three underground sewer lines in the project area that will be impacted.
The first and second line impacted consist of a vertical spacing of 125-ft. and a
horizontal spacing of 139-ft. located in the intersection of US 51B and I-12 near
the Waffle House. The third line impacted consists of a vertical spacing 298-ft.
located within the intersection of Club Deluxe Road and US 51B The sewer lines
are owned by the City of Hammond
A reasonable alternative being Alternate C includes refurbishing existing pavement and
striping with pavement widening. Alternate C has made accommodations for significant
U-turns movements for the access of driveways in the project corridor. Access to
driveways from Interstate 12 or to return to Interstate 12 will require U-turn movements
at the Club Deluxe Road roundabout. Driveways on either side of the median are
accessible by utilizing U-turn movements accommodated by successive roundabouts.
Improvement features considered under Alternate C include:

text.i: UA-1 Principal Urban Arterial (Club Deluxe Road to I-12)
UA- 2 Minor Urban Arterial (Ponchatoula Creek to Club Deluxe
Existing R/W, 8 ft. back of curb (minimum)

page.text: 3.5.2 Major Design Features of Alternate C
To improve the flow of traffic and reduce congestion in the project area, the distance
between traffic signals is increased by utilizing median treatments and roundabouts at
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
Median width is the dimension between the edges of travel ways. Alternative C strives to
implement a median treatment intended to prevent access between travel ways.
Treatments may include a widened median, though unusually wide medians may lend to
undesirable driving behavior. Concrete barriers can be an effective measure, though the
high center of gravity of large trucks may be a condition to cause overturning. Barrier
curb along the median will generally restrict all but the most determined drivers. This
common determination to cross barrier curbing in lieu of the U-turn at the roundabouts is
foreseeable in this project environment. Landscaping may be suitable as a median
The prevention of midblock left turns can be desirably supported by multiple roundabouts
providing sufficient U-turn opportunities for wanting left-turning traffic.
Roundabouts are a type of circular intersection that eliminates left turn movements,
reducing potential conflicts between vehicles and improves the efficiency of an
intersection. Make only right turns upon entry to a roundabout and use a right turn signal
to exit a roundabout. Yield on entry, waiting for a gap in the circulating traffic before
Roundabouts are designed to accommodate large truck and trailer combinations, tire
trucks, buses, and emergency vehicles. A truck apron is the center island built with a
gradually sloped and flat curb. The apron provides long vehicles to make turns within the
roundabout. Trucks should stay close to the left side on approach of the entry and as
For multiple lanes of entry as seen in Alternate C, trucks may use both travel lanes to
travel through the roundabout as efficiently as possible. Approaching the roundabout, a
truck may straddle both lanes and passenger vehicles should drop back behind the truck
When an emergency vehicle enters a roundabout with lights or sirens sounding, continue
to the intended exit and then pull over to the side of the road. If approaching a
roundabout, pull over if room is available, otherwise continue through and pull over upon
exiting. Do not stop in a roundabout which may block the path of an emergency vehicle.
Simple lane use signs are to direct traffic into the correct approach lanes to circulate more
safely without the need to change lanes. Street name signs on the splitter-islands indicate
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
the correct exit to circulating drivers. Signs need to be seen early to avoid sudden exit
maneuvers. Fish hook lane arrows in the circulating road can aide in specifying lane use.
3.5.4 Detailed Investigation of Right-of-way and Displacement
The acquisition of right-of-way is minimized by using curbed roadways and shoulders.
This allows for a minimum of eight feet beyond the back of curb for roadway right-of-
way. For Alternate C there are at least three private properties that improvements will
The Deluxe Harvest Fruit and Vegetable Stand located in the northwest quadrant of the
US 51B and Club Deluxe Road intersection and apparently sits upon a tract of land with
approximately 250-ft. of frontage on US 51B and 300-ft. of frontage along Club Deluxe
Road. The fruit stand building can be avoided by the improvements but it would not be
practicable for the operation of the stand to function so close to the improved roadway.
However, there appears to be sufficient remaining acreage to reconstruct the fruit stand
structure on the residual property. Driveway access to the fruit stand is restricted to a
The Whiskey Bin Bar is located in the southwest quadrant of the US 51B and Club
Deluxe Road intersection and apparently sits upon a tract of land with approximately
352-ft of frontage along US 51B and 225-ft. or so along Club Deluxe Road. The
structure can be avoided by the improvements by using a curbed roadway and a minimum
right-of-way of 8-ft. from back of curb. However, the structure would be very near the
right-of-way and existing parking circulation would be adversely impacted. Driveway
access to the bar is restricted to a distance of 100-ft. from the roundabout.
T.K. Valve Company is located along the eastern side of US 51B and apparently sits
upon a tract of land with approximately 543-ft. of frontage along US 51B. There is an
existing driveway located at Club Deluxe Road and is included in the signal cycle of the
intersection. The required right-of-way for Alternate C encroaches on the front parking
lot and also adversely impacts access to the front parking lot when restricting driveway
A large oak tree is located at the edge of the existing right-of-way and the existing
driveway at T.K. Valve Company. This oak tree will be removed.
It appears as though additional right-of-way will be required for Alternate C.
3.5.4 Detailed Investigation of Utility Relocation Impacts
The information presented in this section will identify the existing utilities affected by
Alternate C of the project. The information contained herein was gathered through
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
topographic survey, field visits, and telephone conversations and meetings with the utility
owners. The facilities affected by the project have been categorized as follows: 1.)
Electric power transmission and distribution lines; 2.) Fiber optic communication lines;
3.) Water lines; 4.) Sewer and sanitary sewer pipelines.
1.) There are three overhead power lines in the project area that will be impacted.
The first line consists of a vertical and horizontal spacing of 536-ft. situated
within the US 51B and Interstate 12 interchange. The second line consists of a
vertical and horizontal spacing of 318-ft. situated within US 51B and Interstate 12
interchange near the Waffle House. The third line consists of a vertical and
horizontal spacing of 469.2-ft. situated within the Club Deluxe Road and US 51B
intersection. The power lines are owned by Entergy
2.) There are two fiber optic communication lines that may be impacted by the
project. The first line consist of a vertical spacing of 287-ft. and the second line
consist of a horizontal spacing of 284-ft. They are both in the location within the
intersection of US 51B and Interstate 12 interchange near the Waffle House. The
owner of the fiber optic communication line is AT&T. The project should have
no or minimal impact on the cables that have a depth of twelve feet.
3.) There are two water lines in the project area that will be impacted. The first line
consists of a vertical spacing of 270-ft. in the location within the intersection of
US 51B and Interstate 12 near the Waffle House. The second line consists of a
vertical spacing of 124-ft. located in the Seale Place Dr. and US 51B intersection.
The water lines are owned by the City of Hammond.
4.) There are four underground sewer lines in the project area that will be impacted.
The first line consists of a vertical spacing of 238-ft. located in the intersection of
US 51B and Interstate 12. The second and third line impacted consist of a vertical
spacing of 294-ft. and a horizontal spacing of 139-ft. located in the intersection of
US 51B and Interstate 12 near the Waffle House. The fourth line impacted
consists of a vertical spacing 382-ft. located within the intersection of Club
Deluxe Rd. and US 51B. The sewer lines are owned by the City of Hammond.
There were several concepts receiving consideration in the development of this project.
The complexities of the corridor and the goals of the project led to evaluation of many of
these concepts. Some of the concepts considered are itemize in the following list and
may be pictured in Appendix B:

Two Lane Roundabout South of Club Deluxe Road and add curbed

Six lanes under I-12 as a separate project or as a part of Alternate B.
Dual left turn lanes at the westbound exit ramp of Interstate 12.

text.b: Preliminary Review Regarding Natural and Human Environment

page.text: A major north-south arterial in the community, US 51B is laced with high density
commercial retail development. The corridor in association with Interstate 12 services
the travelling public with hotels, restaurants, gas stations with USTs (Underground
Storage Tanks), and the trucking industry.
Major land use features in the project corridor have generally developed by common type
and common location. Of course, with higher traffic volumes associated with an
interstate corridor, a more densely development occurs near the interchange that tends to
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
support shopping, travel, and services. The farther removed from the Interstate 12
corridor, unimproved lands remain a dominate feature serving as low density residential,
forested, grazing, and farmstead. However, frontage along the corridor, though still
consisting of many open tracts, the land use is supportive of major medical features.
Community features and land uses along the corridor are illustrated on a map of Major
Generators, shown in Appendix B, and may include such developments as:
1. Hammond Mall and numerous strip malls
2. Pilot and Petro Truck Stops and supporting filling and convenience stations.
3. Hotels include the Days Inn and Colonial Inns.
4. Industrial sites such as Speedco, TK Valve Co., Boh Brothers, and Auto Care.
5. Medical facilities may include the North Oaks Medical Center, Oschner’s Clinic,
Medical Center Drive facilities, Veteran’s Plaza, St. Luke’s Surgery, Delta Health,
6. A large single family neighborhood is being constructed across and along the banks

text.b: 4.2 Perform Initial Check for Potential Impacts to the Environment

page.text: During the course of the Stage 0 study, there were several meetings held with project
personnel, local officials, and interested citizens. Designated scoping meetings included
the project initiation meeting; the alternatives review meeting, the meeting with public
officials, and the public meeting. At each meeting comments were received and
evaluated for implementation in the alternatives. The meeting notes, attendees, and
comments are listed in the Appendix of the report.
Rare animals of Louisiana with habitat in the Tangipahoa Parish area or in the proximity
of the project area may include:
1. The very large raptor, Bald Eagle, Haliaeetus leucocephalus, which in
Louisiana nests primarily in southeastern coastal parishes at the tops of cypress
trees near open water during winter and early spring.
2. The large, docile, barrel-shaped aquatic mammal, Manatee, Trichechus
manatus, rare in Louisiana river basins, such as Pearl, Pontchartrain, and
Barataria, is herbivorous feasting on submerged aquatic beds or floating
3. A large, primitive, relatively stocky, cylindrical fish, Gulf Sturgeon, Acipenser
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
oxyrinchus desotoi, imperiled in Louisiana, has been found in large rivers of
the Lake Pontchatrain watershed, the Pearl, Bogue Chitto, and Tchefuncte,
during late winter and early spring spawning. This bottom feeder’s habitat is
4. The large dark-brown to grayish-black terrestrial turtle with elephantine hind
feet and shovel-like forefeet, Gopher Tortoise, Gopherus poliphemus,
threatened in Louisiana, diet on grass and small herbaceous plants found in the
upland longleaf pine forests of Tangipahoa Parish.
5. The relatively small woodpecker with black back and wings with prominent
white bars, Red-cockaded Woodpecker, Picoides borealis, rare in Louisiana,
feeds on a variety of insects beneath the barks of longleaf pine and mixed pine-
upland hardwood forests with little mid-story found in Tangipahoa Parish.
The southern part of Tangipahoa Parish is the home to the Joyce Wildlife Management
Area which is located approximately five miles south of Hammond, Louisiana along
Interstate 55. The wetland area is primarily cypress-tupelo swamp of the Pontchartrain
Basin. As a waterfowl resource, Joyce Wildlife Management area can support game
The Louisiana Scenic River Act is a unique state river regulatory and protection program
for rivers, bayous, and streams designated by the Louisiana Legislature and administered
through the Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries. Waterways of Tangipahoa
Parish designated as such may include:
1. The Tchefuncte River and its tributaries in Washington, Tangipahoa, and St.
Tammany Parishes, from its origin in Tangipahoa Parish to the juncture with
2. The Tangipahoa River from the Louisiana-Mississippi state line to the I-12
3. The West Pearl River in Washington and St. Tammany Parishes, from the state
line to its entrance into Lake Borgne.
4. The Tangipahoa River in Tangipahoa Parish from the Interstate 12 crossing to
It appears as though that Ponchatoula Creek, located in the project area is not a part of the
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
Trees in good health located within or near highway right-of-ways that are considered
aesthetically important, having a form that separates it from surrounding vegetation or
has historical significance, by policy, are to receive sensitive treatment in design,
construction, and maintenance of highway improvements. Considerations for such trees
are to be identified with recommendations from the Roadside Development Coordinators
There is apparently such a tree located on the east side of US 51B near the Club Deluxe
Road intersection. Alternate A provides for the tree to remain whereas Alternates B and
Located a mile or so southwest of Hammond on Happywoods Road, the two-story framed
bungalow, The Carter House (c. 1925), built by a founder of Southeastern College in
Hammond, is merited by the State Historic Preservation Officer.
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency lists an Environmental Interest Profile on the
following locations in the project area:
It is not apparent from a search of the Department of Natural Resources database that oil
or gas wells exist in the project area.
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
Should transportation policies lend to an inequitable burden on the disadvantaged, the
recourse is environmental justice. Though, no such condition is readily apparent in the
On board informatics at city-data.com provides various demographics for Tangipahoa
d) Population density approx. 140 per square mile
h) Group quarters: College dorm 39%; Assisted 22%; Incarcerated 17%;
l) Education: High school 72%; Bachelors degree 16%
m) Residences with income below poverty 23%
n) Transportation mode: Car alone 79%; carpool 14%; Other 7%
o) The number of vehicles per 1000 involved in fatal accidents in Tangipahoa Parish
is greater than twice that of the state.
Water wells located within a one mile radius are listed in Appendix E.
Construction in the project corridor of any of the alternatives or conceptual schemes
requires conventional construction and roadway improvement methods. Much of the
construction can be accomplished with minimal alteration to normal traffic operations.
Tangipahoa Parish Public Transit System operates as an on-demand minivan service for
the general public with accommodations for special disabilities.
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
A Greyhound Bus Stop is located near the Interstate 12 interchange along US 51B and
provides limited schedule service, which does not support a full-service terminal or
agency. As a general rule, no ticketing, baggage, or package express service is offered at
this location. Greyhound busses may traverse the project area.
Technological advances have produced opportunities for safer and more efficient
transportation systems. The implementation of monitoring devices such as tilt, pan, and
zoom cameras at area of high congestion provide capabilities for improved management.
Visual monitoring can increase safety and efficiency in areas of traffic control
management, incident management, and emergency management.
Presently landscaping along the route, if any, is located outside the highway right-of-way.
Consideration for landscaping in the project area can be foreseen for the roundabout
locations and is to be coordinated in a safe and functional manner. Similarly, median
landscaping may be considered in appropriate locations.
1. Upkeep of landscaping will be by permit/agreement with the community.
2. Conduits for watering and electrical service should be provided for the central
3. No hard wall, fountain or pedestrian encouraging objects are suitable for a
4. Landscape features must ensure adequate sight distance throughout life of the
5. Trees, planters, or poles are not appropriate for splitter islands or near of yield
Additional roadway lighting does not appear to be an integral part of this project.
However, the roadway lighting necessary for all roundabout locations is to have
There is a railroad corridor parallel to the project about a quarter mile east along Club
Deluxe Road. The interstate bridge across the railroad just east of the US 51B
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
interchange is not long enough to provide a crossing for the railroad and a local road.
Traffic congestion is therefore confined to the project corridor when crossing Interstate
12 as having to cross the railroad restricts the opportunity of alternate routes. Similarly,
the eastbound Interstate 12 entrance ramp has grade and length restrictions due to the
5.1.1 Highest & Best Use of Each Individual Property Located
Properties fronting on the project corridor are typically commercial businesses with a
limited mix of long time residences. Some of the residences are being converted to
commercial uses. The highest and best use of properties along the corridor is
Each alternative is supportive of existing land uses being continued as such. The
opportunity for redevelopment in the immediate corridor will be practical with the
Properties are typically large rural tracts that have been or are being converted and
partitioned into uses in the service industry. Interstate 12 and the two major truck stops
are the dominant economic generators providing support for fueling stations, convenience
The medical corridor along US 51B, south of Club Deluxe Road, is centered on North
Oaks Medical Center and the growing surroundings medical clinics, plaza, and support
offices. Convenient access to the medical corridor is hampered by congestion
5.1.4 Consultant fees for Appraisers & Other Specialists
Evaluation of property values and the cost displacements for properties that may be
adversely affected by additional right-of-way needs for the project may be completed in
house by the Department’s Real Estate Section or by an outside consultant. It appears
that three, possibly four, properties may be affected by the project, depending on the
Prepared by Shread-Kuyrkendall & Associates, Inc. with Urban Systems, Inc.
for the Department of Transportation and Development - State of Louisiana
Should the project advance along, there is a preferred point in the design process where
ownership of affected lands is to be confirmed. For these parcels, the confirmation of
ownership will require a formal Title Research Report and the preparation of right-of-
way maps identifying the amount and location of lands to be acquired. The description of
buildings near the project right-of-way and the area of the tract that will be impacted by
the project will also be shown on the right-of-way maps.
Apparent utilities located in the project area that are to be included in a conceptual utility
relocation cost estimate include a sanitary sewer system, a storm drain system, overhead
electrical lines and waterlines. Available preliminary information indicates the length of
existing lines that may be impacted by construction. This information is tabulated as:
Though the environmental impacts of any of the three alternates do not appear to have
significant impacts, the complexities of right-of-way acquisitions and relocations, and the
reconfiguration of ramps on the federal interstate system, it is apparent that additional
environmental review will be necessary to meet NEPA requirements. The cost estimates
include possible requirements for each alternate, a categorical exclusion, an
environmental assessment, and an environmental impact statement.
The design of the project appears to be of average complexity and the cost for basic
design services can be expressed as a percentage of the construction cost. Typically, the
ASCE median compensation curve may be appropriate for fee determinations.
